Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Academic and Research Skills for Business Success
headline: Learn how to use academic research skills to grow your business with this free online research methodology course.
description: Do you want to enhance your academic and research skills and apply them in the business world? This research methodology course explains how to use the research skills that are normally associated with academe to grow your business. Research provides a solid foundation for your ideas and opinions and lets you make decisions with confidence but it requires mastery of established academic methods. This course provides these skills and techniques.
courseDescription:
Research is the driving force behind human progress and is fueled by our natural curiosity. To satisfy this curiosity, we ask questions, analyse data and immerse ourselves in learning processes. Without inquiry and a healthy dose of curiosity, our knowledge and progress would stall and the modern world would be entirely different. Research broadens our field of knowledge, helps to increase people’s credibility, brings people closer, aids in solving problems and helps companies scale new heights. Its benefits are multifold and its impact on our collective curiosity and progress cannot be overstated. By utilising appropriate research methods and techniques, anyone can conduct research that produces precise and dependable results. This research methodology course equips you with the skills and strategies required to conduct proper research and obtain the information and solutions you need. We show you how to apply these methods in the world of business and cover diverse topics like assessments, business plans, research reports and more.

We start by introducing you to the concepts of objectives and scope, self-assessment and personal management skills. We'll identify the qualities that students studying business and management should have, including the organisational skills that are crucial for conducting research. We then compare primary and secondary types of background research and their research roles. We study the various types of interviews used in research, including structured and unstructured interviews. The course examines different types of questionnaires and lays out their advantages in terms of research. Recording information from various sources or platforms as a researcher can free you from the shackles of having to recall vital information, which is why note-taking is crucial to the research process as it enables effective information recording and data storage and analysis. We show you how to effectively take and write notes and provide effective reading strategies used to improve memory and comprehension.

The course then moves on to the concept of ‘active listening’ and discusses its purpose and benefits. We show you how to plan research and write a research proposal. We then explain how experienced readers of business plans review and evaluate them and lay out the dos and don'ts of writing a successful business plan. The course includes a data science section that provides data analysis methods. Finally, we take you through the steps of reaching research conclusions and provide effective ways to interpret and communicate research findings while making recommendations and identifying research limitations. Research is widely recognised in the business field and the academic community. It helps us to understand the world around us, make decisions, identify goals and resolve issues. This research methods course has no prerequisites and is designed for anyone who wants to acquire these skills, from students to business moguls. Research plays a key role in business so sign up to hone your research skills and learn how to apply them to grow your business.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Upon completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain how to conduct research 
    • List the two types of background research.
    • Distinguish between the two types of background research.
    • Indicate the different types of interviews and their advantages.
    • Describe how to make and take notes effectively.
    • Discuss the SQ3R technique used to improve reading efficiency.
    • Recall the purpose and benefits of active listening.
    • Analyse how business plans can be evaluated.
    • Discuss the methods of data analysis.
    • Explain the goals of research reports and presentations.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Here are the key points in this module:
    • Self-assessment is not only a means of measuring continuous improvement; it also provides an excellent opportunity for integrating business or organisational excellence into normal business activity.
    • A key step in the process of defining objectives and scope is forming the assessment team.
    • The data collection phase is governed by two factors, namely: the objectivity required and the resources available.
    • The feedback report is a rich source of improvement opportunities.
    • There are two types of background research: primary research and secondary research.
    • The primary type of research can be qualitative or quantitative.
    • Plagiarism is a serious offence, and universities may use plagiarism-detection software to catch students who cheat with their work.
    • SQ3R is a reading strategy designed to help students improve their comprehension, memory, and efficiency in reading.
    • Active listening is a helpful method that demands you to listen to a speaker attentively, grasp what they are saying, reply and reflect on what is being said and preserve the information for later use.

    • The feedback report is a rich source of improvement opportunities.

    • The primary type of research can be qualitative or quantitative.
    • Plagiarism is a serious offence, and universities may use plagiarism-detection software to catch students who cheat with their work.
    • SQ3R is a reading strategy designed to help students improve their comprehension, memory, and efficiency in reading.
    • Active listening is a helpful method that demands you to listen to a speaker attentively, grasp what they are saying, reply and reflect on what is being said and preserve the information for later use.
